properties.name: 7Seasons apartments
properties.note: Staying in front of the building towards the arc go 10 meters into the arc and find the first door on the left. Then go to the second floor where the reception is.

properties.name: Mlinar
properties.note: A newly-opened chain of bakeries from Croatia. My recommendation: Meat (or fresh cheese) burek with a yogurt drink. A tasty specialty from the Balkans.

properties.name: Cserpes Tejívó
properties.note: Cserpes is a famous dairy producers that supply many shops and restaurants in Budapest. This tejívó place also serves delicious and cheap sandwiches. My recommendation: Mangalica sausage sandwich and a Cocoa Snail (kakaós csiga) for dessert.

properties.name: Ring Café
properties.note: Great burgers

properties.name: Big Fish
properties.note: Seafood restaurant with high quality products. Pricy.

properties.name: Spíler BistroPub
properties.note: Great burgers. Booking only from Sun to Wed.

properties.name: Budapest Bagel
properties.note: Good bagels. Open from noon.

properties.name: The Donut Library
properties.note: You like reading? You like donuts? Welcome to the Donut Library where you can enjoy your favorite sugar-bomb treat while reading a book from the shelves (in Hungarian only). My recommendation: the pistacchio donut.

properties.name: Panini Café
properties.note: A small restaurant on the banks of the Danube. Ideal for a quick toasted sandwich or a nice brunch. They have vegan meals.

properties.name: Kispiac Bistro
properties.note: Located next to the market on Hold utca. Very good meat selection. Friendly mom-and-pop atmosphere but very small.

properties.name: Pár Perc Krumpli
properties.note: The restaurant is almost litteraly a hole in the wall but don't let it fool you. Its Belgian-style French-fries are one of the best in Budapest. Sadly, the rest of its offerings (like the burgers) isn't quite as good.

properties.name: Hummus Bar
properties.note: A popular chain of hummus restaurants around Budapest. Friendly staff and good food for affordable prices. All restaurants more or less share the same menu but some are vegetarian-only. My recommendation: Shakshuka (with mergez sausage if that's your thing)

properties.name: Hummus Bar
properties.note: A popular chain of hummus restaurants around Budapest. Friendly staff and good food for affordable prices. All restaurants more or less share the same menu but some are vegetarian-only. My recommendation: Shakshuka (with mergez sausage if that's your thing)

properties.name: Hummus Bar
properties.note: A popular chain of hummus restaurants around Budapest. Friendly staff and good food for affordable prices. All restaurants more or less share the same menu but some are vegetarian-only. My recommendation: Shakshuka (with mergez sausage if that's your thing)

properties.name: Bite
properties.note: A large selection of sweet and savory bakery products. Ideal for a quick bite. My recommendation: the cheese pretzel (sajtós perec)

properties.name: La Delizia
properties.note: Home baked cookies in a relaxing atmosphere. Large selection of home baked products and friendly staff.

properties.name: Ganga Vega Café
properties.note: Vegetarian restaurant with tasty indian dishes. Very cheap.

properties.name: Sugar!
properties.note: Both a candy shop and a novelty bakery. Not the best bakery in Budapest but definitely the most unique-looking. If you're a fan of Jelly Beans, you can buy them by the color.

properties.name: Hadik
properties.note: Old café where Hungarian intellectuals used to meet. Small menu but good food. Not too far from the Gellért baths.

properties.name: Castro
properties.note: A good restaurant with cheap daily offerings close to the center. Note that they only accept cash. My recommendation: Rakot Krumpli with sour cream and sour cucumbers. A classic Hungarian dish made of layers of baked potatoes, spicy paprika sausage and eggs.
This bar in the jewish district also has a very good menu. My recommendation: Go with a friend (or three) and try the Serbian meat platter (huge portion).

properties.name: Szimpla Kert
properties.note: You will find this bar in all tourist guides; its atmosphere is unique, and while it is usually quite crowded and visited by more tourists than locals, it is a nice place to see, at least once. Arrive early and you can find seats and have a great chat with beers and a traditional Hungarian burger (beware, it is a big one!)

properties.name: Instant
properties.note: Ruin pub with a party place in the basement

properties.name: Anker Klub
properties.note: While this place is a bit less crowdy than the others, it is a nice place to have a drink and chat.

properties.name: Fogasház
properties.note: This bar is a typical ruin pub. It is also a nice place to chat, the music usually isn't too loud compare to other places.

properties.name: Corvintető
properties.note: This club is situated on the top of an old shopping mall. Once you get to the top of the building (by the stairs, or with the elevator if it is open), you get to choose between a bar and house music, and the roof without music. It is nice, but in October it might not be a good idea! :) Since there are DJs every evening, you will have to pay a fee before to get in though.

properties.name: A38
properties.note: A bar on a boat. Concerts almost every night. Great atmosphere. Check their websites for the program before you go there.

properties.name: Nyugati Station
properties.note: It is the Western railway station, designed by Eiffel. It has this old communist style to it, make sure you go inside, you will take great pictures!

properties.name: Gellért Baths
properties.note: Not as big as Szechenyi, but nice anyway!

properties.name: Széchenyi Baths
properties.note:
Not to be missed, plan at least 3 hours to enjoy the outside baths, as well as the saunas, hammams and inside baths. 
Prefer to go there in the afternoon, around 5PM, so that you experience bathing at night. The lightings and the hot water are quite an experience then!

properties.name: Nagy Csarnok / Great Market Hall
properties.note: It is a nice place if you are looking for Hungarian food and drinks. If you're hungry, you'll find small restaurants on the top floor. Closed on Sundays and only opens till 3pm on Saturdays (wekkday opening hours are 6am - 5pm)

properties.name: Batthyány tér
properties.note: The place itself is nothing special, but you'll get a great view over the parliament on the other side of the Danube. Get there with the Subway line 2.

properties.name: Clark Ádám Square
properties.note: From there, you can climb up to the castle and enjoy the view. Take the stairs instead of the funicular, it's free and you'll have time to take pictures!

properties.name: Fisherman's Bastion
properties.note: From there, you'll get a great view over the city and the parliament.

properties.name: Heroes square
properties.note: One of the most popular monuments of Budapest. You can't miss that one!

properties.name: Saint Stephen's Basilica
properties.note: It's worth paying to climb at the top. You'll get a nice view of the city center.

properties.name: Dohány Street Synagogue
properties.note: Largest synagogue in Europe, and 3rd largest in the world.

properties.name: Nice point of view over the river and the Parliament
properties.note: Get off the tram in the middle of the bridge. That's also the entrance of Margaret island.

properties.name: Margaret Island
properties.note: Cars are forbidden on the island, so it's a nice place to go for a walk or a run if you have enough of the city! There is a small zoo on the island, as well as a few bars. There is also a 5350 metre long, rubber-coated running track all around the island.

properties.name: Terror Háza Múzeum
properties.note: This museum retraces the history of Hungary during and after WW2. Intersting to get a view of the communist area and the Nazi occupation. Plan for a few hours, there is a lot to see.

properties.name: Hungarian National museum
properties.note: Temporary exhibitions. Right now, Hungarian painting in the 18th and 19th centuries.

properties.name: Citadella
properties.note: Great panorama over the city. it can be cold up there, so don't go there if it's windy! You can take the bus to get there, but I'd suggest taking the stairs starting at Gellért Tér and climbing the hill, you can stop and take nice pictures on the way. Count 15-20 minutes to get to the top.

properties.name: Nice point of view over the Danube and the Castle
properties.note: You want to come here during the night. The castle looks great in the evening, and that's the best point of view!

properties.name: Embassy of the United States
properties.note: Just in case! :)
